text: This event is later recounted in chapter 14 by Ilya, but there *he* is the furrier under the stairs (R255/E187). D. Barton Johnson summarizes: "Orina's story has strange echoes in Il'ya's later life. After parting from Orina, Il'ya sets himself up as a fur-dresser/cobbler [...] Living in a room beneath the stairs, he befriends an old woman rag-picker and her mentally retarded ward whom he seduces when she brings him an animal hide. Their assignations take place in his room and under a beached boat, but the relationship ends when the pregnant girl takes up with the local sailors [...] The fox-fure slippers made for Orina by her cobbler-seducer foreshadow the unknown article made by cobbler Il'ya for the slow-witted girl who is Orina's successor" ("The Galoshes Manifesto" 153–164). Olga Matich reads Sokolov's novel as an extended response to Boris Pilnyak's short story "Mother Earth" (1927), as it shares confusion between a wolf and a fox, a character name Arina, and a setting on the Upper Volga, among other similarities ("Sasha Sokolov" 312–313). Read the original [here](http://az.lib.ru/p/pilxnjak_b_a/text_1924_mat_syra_zemlya.shtml).
